div.p: I write this not knowing whether the cotton which I shall start with to the river will ever reach there. If the trip succeeds Mr Boyd will will have recd from me 51 bales of cotton. Out of the proceeds he is to hand you $3000, and apply the remainder to my debt to him.
It is impossible to describe to you the state of scarcity here. The cotton burning demoralizes every thing: and throws the dregs of the stagnated water upon the surface.
I have been here a week, walked from the river in the night, and started the wagons for the next
in time to have it al home by day light in the morning. My health has improved.

Affairs were all right at the plantation and had nothing to complain of but the misconduct of the overseer who has been dismissed. Young Andrew is here and is helping me at the place. He had the vareslord, but is now well. There are no new cases.
Write me when you have an opportunity. I thank Jackson for his letter.
